General course objectives:
General course objectives
This course provides an introduction to machine learning (ML) within the realm of protein engineering, covering fundamental ML models, principles, and their applications in protein design. Participants will gain hands-on experience within cloud computing/HPC (high performance computing), delve into generative models for protein design, and understand the structure and functionality of protein language models. This includes designing and engineering proteins using state-of-the-art ML methods. Through group projects and presentations, students will demonstrate their practical understanding and application of the course material.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Summarise the basics of artificial intelligence (AI) and its application in protein design, including key machine learning (ML) models and principles.
Describe and analyse protein structures to be able to integrate this into the protein design and engineering process.
Use cloud computing/HPC for computational tasks related to protein engineering and machine learning.
Explore and analyze various models for representation learning and their specific applications in protein design/engineering.
Design protein structures using advanced ML tools, understanding their mechanisms and applications.
Improve and create simple machine learning models for protein science.
Evaluate the principles of diffusion generative models and apply them to the field of protein design.
Implement the learned concepts in a practical setting through group projects.
Disseminate learned knowledge orally in a precise and approachable fashion.
Discuss where and how artificial intelligence can be used within protein science.
Content: Through lectures, exercises, and group work, this intensive 3-week program will cover basic theory, application, and analytical approaches within the realm of machine learning in protein science. The course is structured to provide a balanced mix of theoretical knowledge and practical skills, engaging students in both foundational concepts and advanced applications. It is meant to illustrate the latest advances, current challenges, and real-life applications of ML-guided protein science across a diverse array of real-life applications within biotechnology, biotherapeutics, and beyond.
